source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Sacrifice the mouse according to animal welfare regulations (see Note 3).

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Transfer the sacrificed mouse to a dissection bench (semi-sterile). Spray the whole mouse and dissection tools with 70% ethanol.

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Remove the skin from the hind limb. Use forceps to lift up the skin at the ankle, and cut the skin with curved scissors up to the region over the knee, thereby exposing the underlying muscles (see Note 4; Fig. 1a). Make sure that no hairs are stuck to the exposed muscles, since they are the highest risk of contamination.

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Remove the fascia surrounding the muscles by ripping them with fine forceps (Dumont 7). Pinch the fascia at the ankle at the side of the tibia bone with the forceps (close the forceps! Otherwise they will bend), and move the forceps toward the knee (Fig. 1b, c). The fascia will rip, and the tendon of the EDL (extensor digitorum longus) at the knee will be visible (Fig. 1d).

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Use curved fine forceps (Dumont 7) to expose the distal tendon of the TA (tibialis anterior) muscle (Fig. 1e; this is the tendon lying on top of the tendons at the ankle). Lift up the tendon with the forceps, and use another set of fine forceps to detach the TA muscle from the underlying EDL (extensor digitorum longus) muscle. Therefore, move the closed forceps up to the knee (approximately up to 0.2 cm below the knee) without injuring the EDL muscle.

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Lift the tendon of the TA muscle with the fine forceps, and cut the tendon with fine spring scissors (Fig. 1f). Pull the TA muscle up to the proximal end (Fig. 1g); cut it at the knee or rip it off (Fig. 1h). The EDL will be fully exposed now (Fig. 1i).

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Grab the now fully exposed tendon of the EDL at the distal end (Fig. 1j; see Note 5), cut the tendon with fine spring scissors (Fig. 1k), and pull the EDL muscle carefully toward the knee (Fig. 1l). Do not touch the EDL muscle and do not stretch the muscle! Only handle the muscle at the tendon (see Note 6).

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: At the knee there are two tendons visible (Fig. 1m). The tendon of the EDL is the one closer to the knee (see also Fig. 1d). Carefully pull the EDL toward the outside of the knee, and then cut the proximal tendon (Fig. 1n). Transfer the EDL gently to the preheated reaction tube containing the collagenase digestion solution (Fig. 1o).

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description: Repeat the procedure with the other leg.

source.title: 3.1 Dissection and Digestion of the EDL Muscle

source.description:
Transfer the reaction tube with the two EDL muscles from one mouse into the
circulating water bath. Incubate until the myofibers are visible (Fig. 2b). The time of digestion is depending on collagenase activity, age of the mouse, and the amount of fibrosis. General digestion times are adult mouse (2–6 months of age),
, and aged mouse (18 months and older),
–
, depending on the amount of fibrotic tissue.

source.title: 3.2 Dissociation of Single Myofibers

source.description:
Transfer the digested EDL muscles into a well of a 12-well plate filled with
(equilibrated in the incubator for about
before use) using the large bore Pasteur pipette (Fig. 2a).

source.title: myofiber isolation medium
3.2 Dissociation of Single Myofibers

source.description: The next steps are done using a stereo binocular microscope with a 0.8–5-fold magnification under a dissection bench (semi-sterile) (see Note 7).

source.title: 3.2 Dissociation of Single Myofibers

source.description: Dissociate the muscles until single myofibers come off using the large bore Pasteur pipette (Fig. 2c; see Notes 8 and 9).

source.title: 3.2 Dissociation of Single Myofibers

source.description:
When about 50 myofibers have come off the muscle, transfer non-contracted single myofibers (shiny bright myofibers; Fig. 2d) into a new well of a 12-well plate filled with equilibrated
. Transfer the myofibers with the small bore Pasteur pipette (Fig. 2a) releasing them gently into the myofiber isolation medium (see Notes 10–12).

source.title: myofiber isolation medium
3.2 Dissociation of Single Myofibers

source.description: Repeat Steps 13 and 14 until you have enough myofibers for your experiment (see Note 12).

source.title: 3.3 Culture of Single Myofibers and siRNA Transfection of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description:
Transfer about 50 non-contracted single myofibers into a well of a 24-well plate filled with
.

source.title: myofiber culture medium
3.3 Culture of Single Myofibers and siRNA Transfection of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description:
Culture the single myofibers in a
incubator with 5% CO2.

source.title: 3.3 Culture of Single Myofibers and siRNA Transfection of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description:
Transfection of MuSCs is done after
of culture using Lipofectamine RNAiMAX: the final concentration of the siRNA equals 5 pmol. Add the reaction mix (
with the respective amount of siRNA in one reaction tube mixed with
and
, and then add the mixture to the
). It is not necessary to change the myofiber culture medium. For longer culture periods (over
), a second transfection after
of culture might be considered.

3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description: Perform the immunostaining using a stereo binocular microscope with a 0.8–5-fold magnification.

source.title: 3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description:
Fix the single myofibers with their adjacent MuSCs using 2% PFA for
at

source.description:

source.title: 3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description: During the final washing steps, label the glass microscope slides on which the myofibers will be mounted. A PAP pen can be used to draw a hydrophobic circle around the edges of the glass slides, thereby avoiding spilling of myofiber containing liquid over the edges of the slide.

source.title: 3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description: After the final washing step, transfer the stained myofibers to the glass microscope slide in the smallest volume possible. Make sure the single myofibers are spread out on the glass microscope slide, so you can count the MuSCs on each myofiber separately.

source.title: 3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description: Remove the liquid with a 200 μl pipette. Make sure that the myofibers are not dragged over the slide; rather leave a little bit of liquid on the slide.

source.title: 3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description: Add two to three drops of mounting medium, and apply a cover slip, thereby avoiding the generation of air bubbles (see Note 15).

source.title: 3.4 Immunostaining of MuSCs on Single Myofibers

source.description:
Let the slides dry at
for at least
–
before analyzing them at the microscope. Make sure that the cover slip is not moving on the slide when counting the cells using a fluorescence microscope. If necessary let the mounting medium harden
at
(see Notes 16–18).

description: The isolation and culture of single floating myofibers with their adjacent muscle stem cells allow the analysis and comparison of muscle stem cells from aged and young mice. This method has the advantage that muscle stem cells are cultured on the myofiber, thereby culturing them in conditions as close to their endogenous niche as possible. Here we describe the isolation, culture, transfection with siRNA, and subsequent immunostaining for muscle stem cells on their adjacent myofibers from aged and young mice.
